title: Operational Practices
description: Comprehensive operational practices for indoor agriculture including daily inspections, harvest clearance, tool accountability, material handling, FIFO rotation, cross-contamination prevention, equipment condition and cleanliness, and facility sanitation

requirements.text: Is there a daily inspection log, including but not limited to, checking worker hygiene (e.g., harvest crew, crop care workers), housekeeping of bathrooms, break area, growing area, and storage area?
mandatoryStatements: Daily inspection log is maintained
Log includes worker hygiene checks for harvest and crop care workers
Log includes bathroom housekeeping inspection
Log includes break area housekeeping inspection
Log includes growing area housekeeping inspection
Log includes storage area housekeeping inspection
Inspections are performed daily before operations begin
Non-conformances identified during inspection are documented and addressed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly review of daily inspection logs for completeness and follow-up on issues
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily completion of inspection log, immediate corrective action for identified issues

requirements.text: Are there records showing that blocks (or coded areas) are cleared for harvest?
mandatoryStatements: Records document clearance of growing areas for harvest
Clearance process verifies area is ready for harvest
Records identify specific blocks or coded areas being harvested
Clearance includes verification of food safety requirements
Authorization by qualified person before harvest begins
Records link harvest clearance to harvest activities
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification that harvest clearance records exist for all harvested areas
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification of harvest clearance before harvest operations begin

requirements.text: Is there a tool accountability program for knives and similar cutting hand tools used in growing and harvesting areas?
mandatoryStatements: Tool accountability program is established for cutting tools
Program covers knives and similar cutting hand tools
Tools are issued and returned with documentation
Tool inventory is maintained showing number and condition of tools
Missing or broken tools are immediately reported and investigated
Tools are inspected before issue and upon return
Records demonstrate tool accountability is maintained
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification of tool accountability records and tool inventory accuracy
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily tool issue and return verification, immediate investigation of missing tools

requirements.text: Are tool dips being maintained properly in terms of anti-microbial solution strength and are records of the solution checks being maintained? AUDITORS SHOULD REQUIRE A TEST AT THE TIME OF THE AUDIT.
mandatoryStatements: Tool dip stations are maintained with antimicrobial solution
Solution concentration is tested and verified regularly
Test results are recorded with date, time, concentration, and personnel
Solution is changed when concentration falls below specification
Testing frequency is appropriate for usage level
Test equipment is calibrated and functional
Records demonstrate proper maintenance of tool dips
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily verification of tool dip concentration testing and records
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Per-shift or hourly testing of tool dip solution concentration, immediate solution change if out of specification

requirements.text: Are raw materials (e.g., seeds, transplants, soil, growing media), finished goods and food contact packaging within accepted tolerances for spoilage and without evidence of adulteration? ANY DOWN SCORE IN THIS QUESTION RESULTS IN AN AUTOMATIC FAILURE OF THE AUDIT.
mandatoryStatements: Raw materials show no signs of spoilage or deterioration
Finished goods are within accepted quality tolerances
Food contact packaging is clean and free from contamination
No evidence of adulteration of any materials or products
Materials showing spoilage or damage are immediately segregated
Quality inspection procedures are in place and followed
Acceptance criteria for materials and products are defined and enforced
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily inspection of raw materials, finished goods, and packaging for spoilage and adulteration
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous monitoring during operations, immediate rejection and segregation of adulterated or spoiled materials

requirements.text: Are materials (commodities, packaging, inputs, etc.) properly marked with codes (receipt dates, manufacture dates, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: All materials are properly marked with identification codes
Codes include receipt dates or manufacture dates as appropriate
Coding system supports traceability requirements
Codes are clearly visible and legible
Coding is applied upon receipt or as specified in procedures
Records link codes to specific material lots or batches
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification that all materials are properly coded and traceable
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily checks of incoming materials for proper coding, immediate coding if missing

requirements.text: Are materials (commodities, packaging, etc.) rotated using FIFO policy?
mandatoryStatements: FIFO (First In First Out) policy is established
Materials are stored and organized to facilitate FIFO
Oldest materials are used before newer materials
FIFO policy is communicated to all relevant personnel
Storage layout and practices support FIFO rotation
Monitoring verifies FIFO policy is followed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification that FIFO policy is being followed in storage areas
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily checks during material usage, immediate correction if FIFO not followed

requirements.text: Does the process flow, facility layout, worker control, utensil control, internal vehicle use, etc. ensure that finished goods are not contaminated by raw materials (e.g., seeds, transplants, soil, growing media)?
mandatoryStatements: Process flow prevents cross-contamination from raw materials to finished goods
Facility layout provides adequate separation of raw and finished areas
Worker movement is controlled to prevent cross-contamination
Utensils and tools are segregated between raw and finished areas
Internal vehicles are cleaned between raw and finished area use
Physical barriers or procedures prevent contamination pathways
Flow analysis identifies and controls all contamination risks
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of process flow and contamination prevention effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily monitoring of segregation practices, immediate correction of cross-contamination risks

requirements.text: Is there proper storage and adequate separation of raw materials (e.g., seeds, transplants, soil, growing media), products and packaging?
mandatoryStatements: Raw materials are stored in designated areas separate from products
Packaging materials are stored separate from raw materials
Physical separation prevents cross-contamination
Storage areas are clearly identified and labeled
Separation distance or barriers are adequate
Storage conditions are appropriate for each material type
Storage layout supports food safety objectives
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly verification of storage segregation adequacy and effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly checks of storage areas, immediate correction if segregation compromised

requirements.text: Are all exposed materials (product, packaging, etc.) protected from overhead contamination (e.g., ladders, motors, condensation, lubricants, walkways, loose panels, degrading insulation, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Exposed materials are protected from overhead contamination sources
Protection includes coverage, barriers, or positioning
Overhead equipment does not drip or leak onto exposed materials
Condensation is controlled and does not drip onto products
Building structure is maintained to prevent falling debris
Walkways and catwalks do not present contamination risk
Regular inspection identifies and corrects overhead contamination risks
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly inspection of overhead areas and protection measures
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual checks for overhead contamination risks, immediate correction if identified

requirements.text: Are all growing areas clean and well maintained; especially lights, ducts, fans, floor areas by walls and equipment, and other hard to reach areas?
mandatoryStatements: Growing areas are maintained clean at all times
Lights, ducts, and fans are clean and free from accumulation
Floor areas by walls and equipment are clean
Hard to reach areas are included in cleaning program
Cleaning frequency is adequate for operational conditions
No accumulation of dust, dirt, or debris in growing areas
Cleaning verification includes inspection of all areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of growing area cleanliness including hard to reach areas
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily housekeeping verification, immediate cleanup of accumulation or debris

requirements.text: Are single service containers used for their intended purpose only so that potential cross contamination is prevented?
mandatoryStatements: Single service containers are used only once for their intended purpose
Single service containers are not reused
Single service containers are not repurposed for different materials
Policy prohibits reuse of single service containers
Personnel are trained on single service container policy
Practice prevents cross-contamination from previous use
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly observation of container use practices
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that single service containers are not reused

requirements.text: Are re-usable containers cleanable or used with a liner and clearly designated for the specific purpose (seeds, product, packaging, etc.) such that cross contamination is prevented?
mandatoryStatements: Reusable containers are made of cleanable materials
Containers are clearly designated for specific purpose (labeled or color-coded)
Containers are cleaned between uses according to SSOP
Alternatively, containers are used with disposable liners
Container designation prevents cross-contamination between different materials
Personnel are trained on container designation system
Container condition allows effective cleaning
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly verification of container designation and cleaning practices
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily checks that containers are used for designated purposes only

requirements.text: Are food contact equipment surfaces free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust and other unhygienic materials (e.g., tape, string, cardboard, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Food contact equipment surfaces have no flaking paint
Food contact surfaces are free from corrosion and rust
No tape, string, cardboard, or other unhygienic materials on food contact surfaces
Equipment surfaces are maintained in sanitary condition
Damaged equipment is removed from service until repaired
Regular inspection identifies equipment condition issues
Repairs are made with food-safe materials
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of food contact equipment condition
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily pre-operational inspection of food contact surfaces, immediate removal from service if conditions found

requirements.text: Are non-food contact equipment surfaces free of flaking paint, corrosion, rust and other unhygienic materials (e.g., tape, string, cardboard, etc.)?
mandatoryStatements: Non-food contact equipment surfaces have no flaking paint
Non-food contact surfaces are free from corrosion and rust
No tape, string, cardboard, or other unhygienic materials that could contaminate
Equipment is maintained to prevent contamination from deterioration
Damaged non-food contact surfaces are repaired to prevent contamination risk
Regular inspection identifies maintenance needs
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly inspection of non-food contact equipment condition
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual checks, immediate repair if contamination risk identified

requirements.text: Does food contact equipment design, placement, and condition (e.g., smooth surfaces, smooth weld seams, non-toxic materials, corrosion-resistant, non-porous, non-absorbent) facilitate effective cleaning and maintenance?
mandatoryStatements: Food contact equipment has smooth, cleanable surfaces
Weld seams are smooth and free from crevices
Equipment is made from non-toxic, food-safe materials
Materials are corrosion-resistant
Surfaces are non-porous and non-absorbent
Equipment design facilitates effective cleaning
Equipment placement allows access for cleaning and maintenance
Equipment condition supports sanitary operations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of equipment design and placement adequacy, quarterly verification of equipment condition
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly inspection of equipment cleanability and condition

requirements.text: Are food contact equipment surfaces clean?
mandatoryStatements: All food contact equipment surfaces are visibly clean
No soil, residue, or buildup on food contact surfaces
Equipment is cleaned according to SSOP
Pre-operational inspection verifies cleanliness
Cleaning frequency is adequate for operations
Cleaning verification is documented
Equipment is protected from contamination between uses
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily pre-operational inspection of food contact surface cleanliness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous monitoring during operations, immediate re-cleaning if contamination occurs

requirements.text: Are non-food contact equipment surfaces clean?
mandatoryStatements: Non-food contact equipment surfaces are maintained clean
No accumulation of dirt, dust, or debris
Cleanliness prevents contamination of food contact areas
Cleaning schedule includes non-food contact surfaces
Cleaning frequency is appropriate for conditions
Non-food contact cleanliness supports overall sanitation
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of non-food contact surface cleanliness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily housekeeping verification, regular cleaning per schedule

requirements.text: Are trash receptacles adequate and placed in suitable locations?
mandatoryStatements: Trash receptacles are adequate in number for volume of waste
Receptacles are placed in convenient and appropriate locations
Placement prevents contamination of product and materials
Receptacles are clearly identified for waste
Receptacles are covered or designed to contain waste
Receptacle locations support good hygiene practices
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of trash receptacle adequacy and placement
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly checks of receptacle condition and placement, immediate adjustment if inadequate

requirements.text: Are all utensils, hoses, and other items not being used, stored clean and in a manner to prevent contamination?
mandatoryStatements: Utensils not in use are stored in clean condition
Hoses are stored off the floor and protected from contamination
Storage method prevents contamination of stored items
Storage areas are clean and organized
Items are protected from dust, pests, and other contaminants
Storage allows drainage and drying where appropriate
Stored items are readily accessible but not in the way of operations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of utensil and equipment storage practices
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification that items are stored properly, immediate correction of improper storage

requirements.text: Are floor drains constructed and located so they can be easily cleaned, do they appear clean, free from odors, in good repair, and flow in a manner that prevents contamination?
mandatoryStatements: Floor drains are constructed for easy cleaning
Drains are located to effectively remove water without creating contamination risk
Drains appear clean without accumulation of debris
Drains are free from foul odors indicating backup or poor maintenance
Drains are in good repair without cracks or damage
Drain flow is adequate and does not cause flooding or pooling
Drain design and flow prevent contamination of product areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of floor drain condition and cleanliness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual checks of drains, immediate cleaning if odors or backup detected

requirements.text: Are internal transport vehicles (e.g., forklifts, carts, pallet jacks, floor cleaners, etc.), clean, do not emit toxic fumes and are being used in a sanitary manner?
mandatoryStatements: Internal transport vehicles are maintained clean
Vehicles do not emit toxic fumes or exhaust in product areas
Vehicles are used in sanitary manner that prevents contamination
Vehicle wheels and surfaces are clean
Vehicles are appropriate for food facility use
Vehicle maintenance prevents leaks or contamination
Vehicle use follows traffic patterns that prevent cross-contamination
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of internal vehicle cleanliness and sanitary use
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily checks of vehicle condition, immediate cleaning if contamination risk identified

capaInject: If daily inspection log not maintained: implement log immediately, train personnel on daily inspection requirements
If harvest clearance not documented: immediate implementation of clearance process, halt harvest until clearance verified
If tool accountability not maintained: immediate tool inventory, implement accountability system within 7 days
If tool dip solutions not maintained: immediate testing and adjustment, increase testing frequency
If spoilage or adulteration found: immediate product hold, segregation, investigation within 24 hours, enhanced inspection
If FIFO not followed: immediate reorganization of storage, retrain personnel within 7 days
If cross-contamination risks identified: immediate implementation of controls, process flow review within 14 days
If food contact equipment condition unsanitary: immediate removal from service, repair or replace before use
If food contact surfaces not clean: immediate cleaning, investigate cleaning procedure effectiveness
traceabilityInject: Daily inspection logs must be traceable to specific dates and inspectors
Harvest clearance records must be traceable to specific growing areas and harvest batches
Tool accountability records must trace tools to specific users and shifts
Tool dip concentration test results must be traceable to specific stations, times, and personnel
Material codes must enable full trace back and trace forward
